oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ammons's four-page letter on U.S. Army stationery to his mother and father describes his first days in the Army. He relates the military routine, getting his dog tags, standing fire watch, and waiting for his uniform. He remarks on the fact that many in his barracks had been in the National Guard, while others were drafted. Ammons enlisted on June 1, 1967, one week after he graduated from high school.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Christopher Ammons was born in Norfolk, Virginia in 1948. He enlisted in the Army on June 1, 1967, and served with the 1st Infantry Division and later with the 194th Military Police Company. He served two tours in Vietnam, 1967-1968 and 1969-1970. Ammons began his service as a replacement after the Tet Offensive and patrolled the Iron Triangle during his 1st tour. He briefly returned to the U.S. in 1968 and was stationed at the armory at Fort Bragg. He returned to Vietnam as an MP in 1969.
